column2: Victory''' is a review by [[W.H. Auden]] of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Return of the King]]''
column3: published in ''The New York Times Book Review''

column1: The article was reprinted in ''[[The Tolkien Scrapbook]]'' ([[1978]]).  Tolkien wrote a commentary about this review which he never sent or showed to anyone else
column2: which [[Christopher Tolkien]] included as [[Letter 183]] in ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''.

[[Frodo Baggins]] fulfills his Quest, the realm of [[Sauron]] is ended forever, the [[Third Age]] is over and [[J.R.R. Tolkien|J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s trilogy [[The Lord of the Rings]]" complete. I rarely remember a book about which I have had such violent arguments. Nobody seems to have a moderate opinion: either
column4: people find it a masterpiece of its genre or they cannot abide it
column5: and among the hostile there are some
column7: for whose literary judgment I have great respect. A few of these may have been put off by the first forty pages of the first chapter of the first volume in which the daily life of the [[hobbits]] is described; this is light comedy and light comedy is not Mr. Tolkien's forte. In most cases
column9: the objection must go far deeper. I can only suppose that some people object to Heroic Quests and Imaginary Worlds on principle; such
column11: cannot be anything but light "escapist" reading. That a man like Mr. Tolkien
column12: the English philologist who teaches at [[Oxford]]
column13: should lavish such incredible pains upon a genre which is
column18:
very shocking.

The difficulty in presenting a complete picture of reality lies in the gulf between the subjectively real
column19: a man's experience of his own existence
column21: his experience of the lives of others and the world about him. Life
column22: as I experience it in my own person
column23: is primarily a continuous succession of choices between alternatives
column24: made for a short-term or long-term purpose; the actions I take
column26: are less significant to me than the conflicts of motives
column28: doubts in which they originate. Further
column29:
my subjective experience of time is not of a cyclical motion outside myself but of an irreversible history of unique moments which are made by my decisions.

For objectifying this experience
column30: the natural image is that of a journey with a purpose
column31: beset by dangerous hazards and obstacles
column33: others actively hostile. But when I observe my fellow-men
column34: such an image seems false. I can see
column36: that only the rich and those on vacation can take journeys; most men
column37:
most of the time must work in one place.

I cannot observe them making choices
column38: only the actions they take and
column40: I can usually predict correctly how he will act in a given situation. I observe
column42: men in conflict with each other
column46: a clear-cut issue between Good on the one side and Evil on the other
column47: though I also observe that both sides usually describe it as such. If then
column48: I try to describe what I see as if I were an impersonal camera
column49: I shall produce not a Quest
column52:
falsify life. There are medieval Quests which deserve the criticism made by Erich Auerbach in his book "Mimesis":

"The world of knightly proving is a world of adventure. It not only contains a practically uninterrupted series of adventures; more specifically
column53: it contains nothing but the requisites of adventure... Except feats of arms and love
column54: nothing occurs in the courtly world-and even these two are of a special sort: they are not occurrences or emotions which can be absent for a time; they are permanently connected with the person of the perfect knight
column55: they are part of his definition
column56: so that he cannot for one moment be without adventure in arms nor for one moment without amorous entanglement... His exploits are feats of arms
column58:
' for they are feats accomplished at random which do not fit into any politically purposive pattern."

And there are contemporary "thrillers" in which the identification of hero and villain with contemporary politics is depressingly obvious. On the other hand
column59: there are naturalistic novels in which the characters are the mere puppets of Fate
column62: from some mysterious point of freedom
column65: Mr. Tolkien has succeeded more completely than any previous writer in this genre in using the traditional properties of the Quest
column68: the conflict between Good and Evil while at the same time satisfying our sense of historical and social reality
column69: it should be possible to show how he has succeeded. To begin with
column72: created an imaginary world and a feigned history in such detail. By the time the reader has finished the trilogy
column73: including the appendices to this last volume
column74: he knows as much about Tolkien's [[Middle-earth|Middle Earth]]
column83:
he knows about the actual world.

Mr. Tolkien's world may not be the same as our own: it includes
column86: beings who know good and evil but have not fallen
column89: do not suffer natural death. It is afflicted by [[Sauron]]
column93: or the [[orcs]] who are corrupt past hope of redemption. But it is a world of intelligible law
column94:
not mere wish; the reader's sense of the credible is never violated.

Even [[the One Ring]]
column95: the absolute physical and psychological weapon which must corrupt any who dares to use it
column96:
is a perfectly plausible hypothesis from which the political duty to destroy it which motivates Frodo's quest logically follows.

To present the conflict between Good and Evil as a war in which the good side is ultimately victorious is a ticklish business. Our historical experience tells us that physical power and
column98: mental power are morally neutral and effectively real: wars are won by the stronger side
column99:
just or unjust. At the same time most of us believe that the essence of the Good is love and freedom so that Good cannot impose itself by force without ceasing to be good.

The battles in the Apocalypse and "Paradise Lost
column100:
for example, are hard to stomach because of the conjunction of two incompatible notions of Deity, of a God of Love who creates free beings who can reject his love and of a God of absolute Power whom none can withstand. Mr. Tolkien is not as great a writer as Milton, but in this matter he has succeeded where Milton failed. As readers of the preceding volumes will remember, the situation in the [[War of the Ring]] is as follows: Chance, or Providence, has put the Ring in the hands of the representatives of Good, [[Elrond]], Gandalf, [[Aragorn]]. By using it they could destroy Sauron, the incarnation of evil, but at the cost of becoming his successor. If Sauron recovers the Ring, his victory will be immediate and complete, but even without it his power is greater than any his enemies can bring against him, so that, unless Frodo succeeds in destroying the Ring, Sauron must win.

Evil, that is, has every advantage but one-it is inferior in imagination. Good can imagine the possibility of becoming evil-hence the refusal of [[Gandalf]] and Aragorn to use the Ring-but Evil, defiantly chosen, can no longer imagine anything but itself. Sauron cannot imagine any motives except lust for domination and fear so that, when he has learned that his enemies have the Ring, the thought that they might try to destroy it never enters his head, and his eye is kept toward [[Gondor]] and away from Mordor and the Mount of Doom.

Further, his worship of power is accompanied, as it must be, by anger and a lust for cruelty: learning of [[Saruman]]'s attempt to steal the Ring for himself, Sauron is so preoccupied with wrath that for two crucial days he pays no attention to a report of spies on the stairs of [[Cirith Ungol]], and when Pippin is foolish enough to look in the [[Orthanc-stone|palantir]] of [[Orthanc]], Sauron could have learned all about the Quest. His wish to capture [[Peregrin Took|Pippin]] and torture the truth from him makes him miss his precious opportunity.

The demands made on the writer's powers in an epic as long as The Lord of the Rings" are enormous and increase as the tale proceeds-the battles have to get more spectacular
column102: the adventures more thrilling-but I can only say that Mr. Tolkien has proved equal to them. From the appendices readers will get tantalizing glimpses of the [[First Age|First]] and [[Second Age]]s. The legends of these are
column104: already written and I hope that
column105: as soon as the publishers have seen "The Lord of the Rings" into a paper-back edition
column106:
they will not keep Mr. Tolkien's growing army of fans waiting too long.

''Mr. Auden is the author of "Nones" and "The Shield of Achilles" among other volumes of verse.''|[[W.H. Auden]]
